paragraphs.text: I find this really sad. Google Books was (and still is) genuinely ambitious, to an almost comical degree. Digitize humanity’s entire corpus of written literature? That’s amazing! Also, good luck.
But there’s something to be said for a commercial giant doing this because it thinks there’s something in it for them. Google is…

a5d4f7eed11e.title: I’m afraid I’m on the side of the authors here.

paragraphs.text: I’m afraid I’m on the side of the authors here. I get what Google wanted to do, but I’m married to a midlist writer (over 30 novels in print) and am friends with many others, some best sellers. Absolutely zero of them wanted anyone to scan their copyrighted work and offer it online without any compensation to them. The people I know who keep…

Good followup piece, Scott. The short answer to your basic question is that Google offered the world a huge gift much greater in power than the small benefit they would receive back for it. And like many good things in life this act of goodness was spoiled by a small number of people who wanted more. In this case the Authors Guild. The Guild is made…
paragraphs.name: 7af6

paragraphs.text: Terrific piece. I hope some added attention to the project will encourage some much needed feature upgrades. I use print.google.com multiple times a day, and have hundreds of books in my library — it’s one of the top 5 things Google has ever done (and is far superior to Kindle in many ways.)

paragraphs.text: Rosenberg’s essay ends with some speculation about letting machines read the texts and studying cross-sections of the corpus for various purposes. These are exactly the uses envisioned for https://www.hathitrust.org/htrc . I don’t see it mentioned anywhere in the essay or in the other comments, so here you go.

f4cafc0c6507.title: For a biography that I am writing I relied on obscure books (from the 1870s-1880s) that showed up…

paragraphs.text: For a biography that I am writing I relied on obscure books (from the 1870s-1880s) that showed up in targeted searches. They provided relevant information, insight and further references. I do not have access to a university library, but thanks to Google Books, I was able to plow ahead from my home computer.

paragraphs.text: I’ve always thought that Internet Archive was in a much better position to become the universal library.
Googles focus seems to be more on organizing and presenting useful information instead of being a library and they have the most useful books in their collection. There is little reason to add more.

paragraphs.text: But it’s also important to know whether they even “thought” to ask in the first place. It’s like when Facebook was violating the Fair Housing Act with its housing ads — was there anyone on staff who actually knew about the law?

f47f209149ea.title: Given the (stupidly short sighted) attitude of Authors Guild I’m not surprised Google have given…

paragraphs.text: Given the (stupidly short sighted) attitude of Authors Guild I’m not surprised Google have given this project lower priority. Still — it’s a great project, for which I am thankful almost everyday. Together with Open Library I have access to a world class digital library service in rural Spain.

210e5ea64dce.title: If you need it — really, aren’t All Things Google about want, not need?

paragraphs.text: If you need it — really, aren’t All Things Google about want, not need? — Google Books has its own search bar now. They changed their listing to highlight the most-used (probably meaning Best Monetized) links, focus more attention on the products they make, and took some things off the list to their own locations.

2a54f3addc8a.name: Spencer Thayer

paragraphs.text: To date, the full experience of reading a book requires human beings at both ends. An index like Google Books helps us find and analyze texts but, so far, making use of them is still our job. Maybe the quest to digitize all books was bound to end in disappointment, with no grand epiphany.
paragraphs.name: 82d8

paragraphs.text: As the Authors Guild’s Gleick points out, Google started Books with a “better ask forgiveness than permission” attitude that’s common today in the world of startups. In a sense, the company behaved like the Uber of intellectual property — a kind of read-sharing service — while expecting to be seen the way it saw itself, as a beneficent pantheon of wizards serving the entire human species. It was naive, and the stubborn opposition it aroused came as a shock.
paragraphs.name: de09
